ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned all sorts of concepts and skills in this course. I had zero programming experience coming into this Summer and now I can code in Java and write programs that work and can actually do things. I learned how to write methods, classes and objects, learned how to use for loops and while loops, and learned how to store things in variables and arrays. I definitely learned a lot this Summer.

By taking this course, I increase more knowledge about computer science  and develop my skill about programming. I can now program by using the visual studio code and java. Also, it improve my English speaking skill.

1. I learnt how to write useful Java programs: using data types (arrays, strings, numbers, lists, queues, stacks, etc.), control structures (conditionals, looping, exceptional handling, recursion, etc.), program analysis (assertions, etc.), basic algorithms (sorting, searching, etc.), object-oriented programming (classes, methods, objects, inheritance, polymorphism, interface, etc.),  and basic libraries (graphics, digital audio, text processing, etc.).
2. I had chances to collaborate with classmates: a precious opportunity to work with excellent partners, which is an indispensable skill for CS programmers.
3. As an international student, I was fully exposed to Yale Culture as well as got kind help and support from Prof., TAs and classmates, which I appreciate a lot.

I learned about the programming language Java. Concepts taught during the summer course include the different types of primitive data, formatting, definite and indefinite loops, object-oriented programming, and many syntax terms.
Coding skills
I leaned the basic syntax and logic to write code in JavaScript. I also learned the fundamental terminology associated with coding.
I learned the basic skills and knowledge of JAVA programming.

I learnt a lot of concepts of java, from primitive data types to object oriented programming. Other than just learning the concept, the activities within the class and the problem set offered me chance to apply the skills I've learnt. Compared to just knowing something about java before this course, I am able to use something after the course, which is much more important.

I choose this course so that I would be able to learn more about what my dad does and what programming is all about. I wanted to see if I could have anything to do with real-life programming, and for that, I required an intense course. Luckily, this program did not disappoint and was exactly what I was looking for. 

I learned all of the basic programming skills and the more complicated ones too, such as creating an entire game. I never thought I would be able to learn how to make a whole game in as short of a time as one week, but I did! (with the help of my classmates and instructors).

I enjoyed the Zoom meetings very much even though I felt like the course was moving along too quickly for beginners. I did appreciate the challenge!

I loved learning more about the logistic way of Java. Everything has a reason and, one little mistake means hours of work to solve it. I think that that was my most valuable lesson: "How to solve problems"
introduction to language  of java and techniques in computer programming.

Practice. Since this introduction class is quite hard, even though I have some basic knowledge, I still need to work very hard to challenge this class. However, a challenging difficulty brings me more things. One example is the homework: hard but solid practice.
I learned a lot about Java programming.
intro to programming
I learned the basics of programming in Java.
Intro to Java and thinking like a programmer.
I developed my coding skills as well as my problem solving skills. I also became much better at working with others through multiple peer programming assignments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I had to learn most of the content via pre-recorded lectures instead of actually being taught by the TAs, I would have liked to be taught by the actual professor instead. The sections involved lots of examples and exercises but not a lot of actual teaching. That being said, the pre-recorded lectures were very helpful and I learned a lot.
The course is good.

Strengths: tons of. Answered in Question1.
It would be fully appreciated if it could be more efficient during Office Hour. It might be better if we try filling questionnaires illustrating our specific questions and get into groups, meet classmates with the same problem and help one another.

Strengths: The psets are thought-provoking and most of the time the results are cool.

Weaknesses: Many students suffered in this class because office hours were understaffed. It was a common occurrence for a person to attend office hours (online), wait for the entire three hours, and never be helped. They were also very adamant in the beginning about not sharing code, which hindered a lot of possible progress that could have been made (and would have alleviated the office hours crowd). They made adjustments during the third week, but eventually the problem set walkthrough slides they posted merely reiterated the directions on the pset. The need for help with psets was necessary because there were many skills that were used in the starter code that students were not familiar with, which means students didn't understand what the program was supposed to do already and what parts they were supposed to fill in.

Communication was shaky at best and completely useless at worst. Responses to emails were erratic and often many hours later. The average response time to posts on ed discussion (well, those they responded to) was probably about 12 hours. The directions for the final project were non-existent (literally, there were no directions provided on the submission page and the only verbal guidance we received was to "make a project in a week"). Grading for psets took forever and absolutely no feedback was provided for docked points.
Paced too fast
The quizzes and psets could be more synchronized with the pace at which the lessons are given.

The strengths of this course were the organization of the sections into level of Java programming experience. I really appreciated that this class was able to accomodate for not only people already quite proficient, but students who have no experience at all. Another strength would be how helpful the TAs were for directing the students during section and office hours. The weaknesses of the course were that the assignments assigned each week were double that of a normal year, which was extremely challenging, especially for students with no coding experience. Another weakness is that the office hours were not efficient due to lack of number of TAs for this course. At many times I would be in office hours for over 3 hours and yet to speak and get help from a TA. This was very frustrating and I hope this can be resolved for next summer.

If I'm really a zero-based programmer, I may need more walkthroughs to finish the assignment because now we only had walkthroughs for the hardest problem sets. I know that we had office hours but most of those time periods are not friendly to international students.

My only problem with the course was OH. 
We all appreciated the existence of these in the course, but the waiting lines were terrible. 
If you had a block you would have to wait for about two hours for someone to help you. Not only was there a short help time but while you waited, there was not much to do since you had a block. 
Some people wasted 4 hours in the waiting line and got told to come back the next day.

It was very chaotic and this could've been organized better. 
The rest of the course was perfect.
As a introduction course, it's really hard for a beginner, especially in the summer session: we need to learn knowledge and master it in such a short time.

It was pretty difficult to try to turn in two psets a week, on the same due date and at the same large workload for each one, during five weeks in the summer. Perhaps if two psets are needed to be turned in a week, they could be smaller and have staggered due dates so we only have to worry about one pset at a time? Having the two discretionary late days for psets was extremely helpful, but perhaps it would be easier for students to receive their grading if the late day was updated to allow students to send the code on Gradescope instead of through email.
it would be great to have more staff at office hours
The course taught useful information, but was taught at such a fast-paced level that it was hard to keep up.

Strengths: Gets a lot of content in.

Weakness: So much content and work in such a small period of time.
Strengths are that it is fast paced and extremely focused. No weaknesses.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I probably would because I did learn a lot, but most of the people I know are already proficient in coding in Java.
I will introduce this course to my friends who are interested in computer science. Because this course could help them learn about that.

Yes!
I have to say that this course intrigues my passion for Computer Science and I will definitely keep working on.
Thanks a lot for that!
No. I am undoubtedly sure you could learn more if you tried with CodeAcademy or just on your own. It would certainly be less of a headache.
I would recommend the course to another student because I thought the hybrid style of video lecture and in person section was easy to learn coding through.
Yes, but only if you take this course during a regular school semester. Summer session was more difficult and stressful than necessary.
Since this is a pretty challenging course, I would recommend it to students who have some programming foundations, or he/she may find it hard to keep up the course.

I definitely would recommend this course to other students.
It's a great way to learn more about programming and how to solve problems. It's beautiful to see how simple but complicated it is, and there is no in-between. In my opinion, I found a strong base of ethics and morality behind computer science.

This course is not only meant for programming and science students but also for the rest. It's a great way to learn more about problem-solving and also a very interesting and professional way to learn more about programming when in high school.
It's a lovely preview of what yale offers educationally and it also shows how interesting the courses are.
I would recommend in order to get a CS requirement for a STEM major out of the way or to learn basic programming.
yeah it think it's a good way to get a cs requirement out of the way
I would recommend this course only if theyre interested in learning programming.
Only if they really need to take it because it goes so fast that it's hard to make sure you're really understanding everything.
Not really - the learning curve was very high despite this supposedly being an introductory course and insufficient support for students with a wide range of coding experience was available.
Yes, it was a lot of fun and I learned a lot!

I would definitely recommend this course to another student because I was able to learn a substantial portion of Java and was even able to enhance my analytical and problem solving skills along the way. Whenever I found myself struggling to solve a problem, I received assistance from my teachers and was able to fill in gaps within my learning. All in all, I really liked this course because I was able to learn Java in a matter of weeks, and it was a mix of fun and challenging.
